text: when i first saw this advert on youtube i cried buckets, but now i find for tv, they have edited the advert so it is shorter, and it does not have the same emotional tear-jerking effect it had the first time round. i guess they don’t want people being blubbering emotional wrecks every time they see it, but i think it has a social and very important role in seeing the advert in its full length. firstly, there is the father/son relationship which also brings on the discussion with fathers as role models and especially the discussion of absent fathers ( including father’s ) who are no longer here in their son’s life. seeing the full length of this advert the way it should naturally be shown, brings the natural message of father and sons relationships, home very clearly, especially at this special time of christmas. red heart
author: @rogerhoward7498
text_final: first saw on youtube cried buckets, but now find tv, edited so shorter, does not same emotional tear-jerking effect had first time round. guess don’t want people being blubbering emotional wrecks every time see it, but think has social very important role seeing its full length. firstly, there father/son relationship which also brings on discussion fathers role models especially discussion absent fathers including father’s no longer here son’s life. seeing full length way should naturally shown, brings natural message father sons relationships, home very clearly, especially at special time christmas. red heart

text: have fun in your youth, dance, get lost in the moment - you’ll probably meet someone magical while doing so - and then fatherhood will (should) yank you away from adolescence, but take that fun and dancing into fatherhood and get lost in the moment blue heart a thing of absolute beauty blue heart well done john lewis and saathci & saatchi, as a father it had me in tears.

text: i kind of love this advert but it chokes me up at the same time . i had the best dad in the world bar none, not perfect but as close as you could get . bought him an album by the four seasons in xmass1975 and this advert is so like that day 50yrs ago . lost dad when he was just 42 in 1985 of cancer . i'm the dad of 4 daughters and 4 grandsons now, still miss dad but this advert really does make me feel like he is close to me still. at 61 now life has gone full circle here's to the next 61yrs and thank john lewis well done you really scored a goal with this years advert . ive watched 3 dozens times already .

( nothing bad just teenage coming age stuff and me also getting into my fifties). as he’s got older the last few weeks i see him as 24 year old man rather than the toddler he was or the petulant teenager messing up his exams. the record is poignant as he’s been helping me do his sisters house up next door to a dj from the most famous rave club in the world x

text: my dad loved his music, and before he died of cancer in 2020 he became a bit hard of hearing, and couldn’t really enjoy his music anywhere near as much because he couldn’t really hear it properly. i decided to give him my sennheiser over ear headphones to see if they made any difference. he tried them and his face lit up, he could hear everything again, all the details in the music that he’d missed for so long. he got to enjoy his music again for about 2 months before he died, and i’m so glad for that. i miss him. this advert resonated with me because it reminded me a little of our situation. well done john lewis for doing something different this year, it’s a great advert.
author: @Stevieboy74
text_final: dad loved music, before died cancer 2020 became bit hard hearing, couldn’t really enjoy music anywhere near much because couldn’t really hear properly. decided give sennheiser over ear headphones see if made any difference. tried face lit up, could hear everything again, all details music he’d missed so long. got enjoy music again months before died, i’m so glad that. miss him. resonated because reminded little our situation. well done doing something different year, it’s great advert.

text: i really appreciate an ad that acknowledges how regular men think. this nails what it feels like to be a dad in my 50's. i'm still the same person who raved at college to the happy mondays, but where did all that time go? i only wish either of my sons would understand me like this guy's kids seem to do. then again, this is part of the ad's appeal. i showed it to my wife, almost in tears, and she didn't get it at all. it's usually the other way around. this highlights the marketing team's understanding of what it's like to be a dad of a teenager these days.
author: @marto1998
text_final: really appreciate acknowledges how regular men think. nails what feels like dad 50's. i'm still same person raved at college happy mondays, but where did all time go? only wish either sons would understand like guy's kids seem do. then again, part ad's appeal. showed wife, almost tears, didn't get at all. usually other way around. highlights marketing team's understanding what like dad teenager these days.

text: great, it's raised awareness, and i think that needs to happen, particularly amongst males, being the most likely to take their own lives in this country, uk. however, this ad may put people under pressure. they are advertising a typical middle class family. the positive comments are most likely coming from this group. if only it was that easy to buy, play a record. for a parent and child to bond. it's not that simple, unfortunately crying face there will be many parents feeling they are lacking, failed due to this advert. there are so many other obstacles in the way. i'm pleased it's raised awareness, but not entirely realistic for the majority. we didn't have social media in the 90s. we have more education and choices now, but unfortunately the damage is done. i chose not to have children due to the way society is changing for the worse. i'm a 40 something woman and a psychiatrist nurse! and don't regret not having kids. in my line of work, we're just picking up the pieces of family breakdowns. the very popular john lewis doesn't show that. don't feel bad, just do your best!
author: @sjs9605
text_final: great, raised awareness, think needs happen, particularly amongst males, being most likely take own lives country, uk. however, may put people under pressure. advertising typical middle class family. positive comments most likely coming from group. if only easy buy, play record. parent child bond. not simple, unfortunately crying face there many parents feeling lacking, failed due advert. there so many other obstacles way. i'm pleased raised awareness, but not entirely realistic majority. didn't social media 90s. more education choices now, but unfortunately damage done. chose not children due way society changing worse. i'm 40 something woman psychiatrist nurse! don't regret not having kids. line work, we're just picking up pieces family breakdowns. very popular doesn't show that. don't feel bad, just do best!

text: it could be just a christmas campaign. and, scientifically, supported by a prior study, based on consulting a consumer panel and on customer-derived insights. thus, technically, compliant. and then, more or less empathetic, with greater or lesser notoriety. and, at the same time, with the assessment of the direct impact generated on the promotional action’s sales. therefore, the consequent final measurement of the results and the return on investment. however, in this brand communication, i perceive a philosophical essence or a “human condition” of christmas — literally, that is, even pre-linguistic if the human being is what they feel, then let us speak of love. without words. sometimes — in excess or at the wrong time — words even prove to be the root cause of the generation gap between parents and children. congratulations to john lewis & partners and to the creative team. for having said so much, simply by playing music. in the hearts. of parents and children. of families. “where love lives” by alison limerick, or the “perseverance of love” of jesus christ. it’s christmas!
author: @leonelribeiropires5552
text_final: could just campaign. and, scientifically, supported by prior study, based on consulting consumer panel on customer-derived insights. thus, technically, compliant. then, more or less empathetic, greater or lesser notoriety. and, at same time, assessment direct impact generated on promotional action’s sales. therefore, consequent final measurement results return on investment. however, brand communication, perceive philosophical essence or “human condition” literally, is, even pre-linguistic if human being what feel, then let us speak love. without words. sometimes excess or at wrong time words even prove root cause generation gap between parents children. congratulations partners creative team. having said so much, simply by playing music. hearts. parents children. families. “where love lives” by alison limerick, or “perseverance love” jesus christ. it’s christmas!

text: my father passed away early this year, and this xmas will be my first xmas without him, without hearing his voice, and without his hug. this ad watered my eyes in ways i didn't think it would be possible. thank you for reminding me what it feels to have had a lovely and strong father i had!

text: what is it for people that makes this so powerful? is it that the dad character is maybe partly wishing he could go. back to simpler times, less stress, less responsibility - in the moment at least, before he had his current life, maybe thinking - oh this is great, if only i could go back, but then he see's his son, who's maybe disconnected from him, they've had their differences in opinions lately, but his face just cries out for love after they've disconnected, and the father realises he doesn't need to go back, what he needs now is right in front of him, together they can love each other, be there for each other and enjoy music together. i'm a dad and that's what it made me feel, it made me cry out of guilt for often wishing i could go back to those dance floors when i was a teenager with no worries. i obviously would never swap those things. to live in the moment!
author: @darrencampbell638
text_final: what people makes so powerful? dad character maybe partly wishing could go. back simpler times, less stress, less responsibility moment at least, before had current life, maybe thinking oh great, if only could go back, but then see's son, who's maybe disconnected from him, they've had differences opinions lately, but face just cries out love after they've disconnected, father realises doesn't need go back, what needs now right front him, together can love each other, there each other enjoy music together. i'm dad that's what made feel, made cry out guilt often wishing could go back those dance floors teenager no worries. obviously would never swap those things. live moment!

text: i can still keep up with the young’uns as long as i got a fresh tank of oxygen and life support nearby, the joy of being middle aged! how i miss those days when you hear your song come on and jump up from your sit. these days you’re more like a demented aged spider-man just looking for something to grab hold of as you find your feet and try to get up from your seat only to reach the dance floor and catch the end of the song. even moving around to your favourite music in your seat is perilous as you butt ain’t that tight anymore and jerk to the left a little too hard and you have silent horrendous smell-bomb violently stinking up the atmosphere immediately around you, that temporarily paralyses you in fear in case you’ve pebbledash your pants!

text: what a absolute bell dinger of an advert! this will mean different things to many people.at christmas as a dad of 2 a girl and a boy aged 17 and 15 we do look back at what we thought were the best time and at that moment they were and should be remembered as such with foundess as they made you the person you are today. life seemed and was much easier as we didnt have the responsibilities and pressures that being a dad brings. it made me remember my late father as well as thanking god for my 2 children. you have to appreciate the here and now enjoying every possilbe moment you share together, it is hard to try and reflect to see where you started to where you are now in life as seasons come and go so quickly it seems these days.
author: @alanmcandrew3486
text_final: what absolute bell dinger advert! mean different things many people.at dad girl boy aged 17 15 do look back at what thought were best time at moment were should remembered such foundess made person today. life seemed much easier didnt responsibilities pressures being dad brings. made remember late father well thanking god children. appreciate here now enjoying every possilbe moment share together, hard try reflect see where started where now life seasons come go so quickly seems these days.

text: jl for me it’s about the words we don’t always know how to say- the teenage son choosing a record isn’t just a gift, it’s a bridge. there’s a strong men’s emotional health thread running through this. men are often raised to 'hold it together', 'be strong', 'say less'. the skill and the compassion is in noticing. that’s what this advert captured for me. don't get me wrong, i was also taken back to the '90's - my gosh it hit a nerve and i downloaded 'the record' ⁠immediately d but what i loved was the point about recognition, empathy, and the quiet bravery of care. the link between dad's and their sons. brilliant.
author: @MsJosiJo
text_final: jl it’s words don’t always know how say- teenage son choosing record isn’t just gift, it’s bridge. there’s strong men’s emotional health thread running through this. men often raised 'hold together', 'be strong', 'say less'. skill compassion noticing. that’s what captured me. don't get wrong, also taken back '90's gosh hit nerve downloaded 'the record' ⁠immediately but what loved point recognition, empathy, quiet bravery care. link between dad's sons. brilliant.

text: oh and i’m not a dad, only have daughters… but i’ve shared many a spliff with my 20 yr old who is a born again 90s raver and festival goer. she doesn’t see me as 53, it feels like we are on a level and she always asks if i’m ok and that in her mind we are both still girls living on earth for the first time. she’s so emotionally mature. more than most adults. the alison limerick track which i haven’t heard since i was about her age just really hit hard and of course i sent her the link straight away ( she’s just started uni and i miss her so so much ) of course she won’t get the message for a few hrs. sat night in liverpool at 20. defo be out living her best life heart hands light skin tone

text: the advertising agency that produced this is swimming against the tide, that is for sure, but that is a masterclass in how it is done. yes, an english family where father and son are centre stage is definitely a welcome change. the musical choice instantly invokes nostalgia for the generation x’ers out there. the tone was perfect and the use of memory of the son from baby to toddler to teenager is powerful stuff. i shop at john lewis and will continue to do so. it is just referring to see fathers, sons and men shown in a positive light for a change.
author: @AlexDeLarge77
text_final: advertising agency produced swimming against tide, sure, but masterclass how done. yes, english family where father son centre stage definitely welcome change. musical choice instantly invokes nostalgia generation x’ers out there. tone perfect use memory son from baby toddler teenager powerful stuff. shop at continue do so. just referring see fathers, sons men shown positive light change.

text: john lewis, you've absolutely smashed it for me this year. i’m 46, and lately i’ve been looking back a lot… my younger self, my rave days, the freedom, the late nights. i miss it more than i expected. these last few years have been rough. my mental health took a dip and it affected my kids. my youngest and i have had the hardest time. my career took over much of my parenting and i missed more than i want to admit. but life has a way of giving us a second chance. this past year he’s had his own struggles, and somehow that opened a space for both of us to heal. he’s helped me. i’ve helped him. we’ve met each other again. and the funny thing is — we found our way back through music. house music. the beats of my younger days. we share songs, talk about memories, dance in the kitchen, gone to gigs different generations, same rhythm. to me, that’s what parenting — and christmas — is about. not being perfect. not getting it all right the first time. but finding a way to reconnect, laugh again, and love each other in real, everyday ways. here’s to second chances. to softer hearts. to music that carries us home. yellow heart
author: @rinbeans
text_final: lewis, you've absolutely smashed year. i’m 46, lately i’ve been looking back lot… younger self, rave days, freedom, late nights. miss more than expected. these last few years been rough. mental health took dip affected kids. youngest had hardest time. career took over much parenting missed more than want admit. but life has way giving us second chance. past he’s had own struggles, somehow opened space both us heal. he’s helped me. i’ve helped him. we’ve met each other again. funny thing found our way back through music. house music. beats younger days. share songs, talk memories, dance kitchen, gone gigs different generations, same rhythm. me, that’s what parenting about. not being perfect. not getting all right first time. but finding way reconnect, laugh again, love each other real, everyday ways. here’s second chances. softer hearts. music carries us home. yellow heart

text: the ad plays around with the notion of father and son, while deploying the terms "words" and "gift". the alison limerick song is meanwhile "where love lives" - a club hit from 1992. that's a gap of 33 years to now, the typical number of years on earth ascribed to the saviour, the word made flesh, the son of the father who rose again and delivered the most loving gift of eternal life to all of us. the album originally including the song was 'and still i rise" - a title that (also) honours the poem of the late maya angelou - a taster of various faiths before deciding on christianity. and so this is christmas. i hope you have fun.
author: @sidpheasant7585
text_final: plays around notion father son, while deploying terms "words" "gift". alison limerick song meanwhile "where love lives" club hit from 1992. that's gap 33 years now, typical number years on earth ascribed saviour, word made flesh, son father rose again delivered most loving gift eternal life all us. album originally including song 'and still rise" title (also) honours poem late maya angelou taster various faiths before deciding on christianity. so christmas. hope fun.

text: yep - this has absolutely fllored me too. cried my eyes out everytime i've seen it. it works on so many levels. i can't beieve we're all discussing a christmas advert but this is such a brilliant and clever ad. if you're a dad with a son this totally nails it. i love the details in it.the son is wearing headphones, he's obviously into music.the way he's looking sad that his dad hasn't seen it.the look from his sister. i'm in the middle of a divorce so this is so poignant. whoever did this ad have just nailed it. i can't believe an ad has affected me so much. also as someone pointed out, an ad where men aren't portrayed as stupid or useless. big up all the dads!

text: i see it as before he had children and a family, his life and joy revolved around raving and that carefree lifestyle. once he became a father, everything changed-those experiences were left behind as his priorities shifted toward his responsibilities. but through the present and the music, he was taken back to that part of himself, reminded of what he once loved. then came the realisation that this part of his life had faded when he became a dad. yet, having his son recognise and connect with that passion-sharing that moment together-was deeply meaningful, because his son is now his whole world.
author: @pt4005
text_final: see before had children family, life joy revolved around raving carefree lifestyle. once became father, everything changed-those experiences were left behind priorities shifted toward responsibilities. but through present music, taken back part himself, reminded what once loved. then came realisation part life had faded became dad. yet, having son recognise connect passion-sharing moment together-was deeply meaningful, because son now whole world.

text: 44 year old mum to an almost teenager and an 8 year old, and i think this is supposed to represent the fun of a lost youth, which pales into insignificance when you have your babies and they change your world - the most important thing is the world you’ve made with your children, everything else is secondary. the son has bought the record to remind the dad of his younger days, but no matter how good those days were, the days that came after, with him in the world, were so much more precious. and the dad clearly appreciates the silent gesture, as your children reach those teenage and pre-teen years, they communicate less and less, but the son is letting the gift speak for him. it’s such a lovely touching advert. probably the best one jl have done yet.
author: @nicolaatkins2348
text_final: 44 old mum almost teenager old, think supposed represent fun lost youth, which pales into insignificance babies change world most important thing world you’ve made children, everything else secondary. son has bought record remind dad younger days, but no matter how good those days were, days came after, world, were so much more precious. dad clearly appreciates silent gesture, children reach those teenage pre-teen years, communicate less less, but son letting gift speak him. it’s such lovely touching advert. probably best one jl done yet.

text: well i didn’t expect that! i thought it would be all about luring people into spend spend spend! spend your money on things because they’re going to say it’s a bargain! i’ve read so many positive and negative comments. i get it. we live in britain, the uk whatever you want to call us and no matter what, there always someone unhappy or got an opinion. fair play, i understand but what i love about this ad is that jl have approached the christmas d in such a different way. made it more emotional and real . not necessarily encouraged us to spend on their website but i know there will be so many out there who were born on the 70’s, raised in the 80’s and raved in the 90’s and this will be a positive reminder see or trigger to share those amazing experiences we had. best gift ever . telling those stories and sharing the music that made us so happy and still does . i felt no need to suddenly buy from their website . it made me want to get my tape deck out and play my 90’s tracks to my 13 yer old and tell him about life without phones, social media, meeting friends without texting . you just knew they’d be there . the time of that alison limerick track was amazing . i know some won’t get it but i do feel a whole lot of you will .and it just prompts you to share your good times and memories and have quality time chattering . best gift ever jl! no commercial pressure to buy buy buy . a lovely advert encouraging good relations and just making time for each other red heart
author: @aliceh1977
text_final: well didn’t expect that! thought would all luring people into spend spend spend! spend money on things because they’re going say it’s bargain! i’ve read so many positive negative comments. get it. live britain, uk whatever want call us no matter what, there always someone unhappy or got opinion. fair play, understand but what love jl approached such different way. made more emotional real not necessarily encouraged us spend on website but know there so many out there were born on 70’s, raised 80’s raved 90’s positive reminder see or trigger share those amazing experiences had. best gift ever telling those stories sharing music made us so happy still does felt no need suddenly buy from website made want get tape deck out play 90’s tracks 13 yer old tell life without phones, social media, meeting friends without texting just knew they’d there time alison limerick track amazing know some won’t get but do feel whole lot .and just prompts share good times memories quality time chattering best gift ever jl! no commercial pressure buy buy buy lovely encouraging good relations just making time each other red heart

text: i think this is rather beautiful and beautifully cast and acted. for me i think there are a mix of meanings running through. i see the main story being that the dad is rather sad and reflects on raising his son and now the son being older. perhaps he is feeling distant from him or the life they live is not what it was. burdens of the now are real and life is.more difficult. so the son does what children do best; he shows loves and gives the dad hope by 'taking him back to a happier time'. he then helps the dad maybe grappling with age and to let go of his youth and reconnect with what is important now; his family. the passing of time with its joy and sadness eh; so lovely to capture this for all us parents. the joy of children and love and the sadness of loss and ageing. there's always time to dance and have a hug with the ones we love. the best tune chosen too! the 90s were a great time to be alive!
author: @RebeccaBradshaw-t7o
text_final: think rather beautiful beautifully cast acted. think there mix meanings running through. see main story being dad rather sad reflects on raising son now son being older. perhaps feeling distant from or life live not what was. burdens now real life is.more difficult. so son does what children do best; shows loves gives dad hope by 'taking back happier time'. then helps dad maybe grappling age let go youth reconnect what important now; family. passing time its joy sadness eh; so lovely capture all us parents. joy children love sadness loss ageing. there's always time dance hug ones love. best tune chosen too! 90s were great time alive!

text: so, an emotionally stunted man has an insidious and pernicious resentment of his (25 year old?) autistic son because he grew up. the son (a people pleaser due to his father's neglect) mirrors his father's awkwardness and is too scared to hand him the thoughtful gift that he naively hopes will make his father validate him as an autonomous person and love him unconditionally. the father is too selfish to do this and continues to infantalise his son to the point of picturing him as a newborn, albeit now at least showing him some of the affection which has clearly been lacking throughout his life. this should be a cautionary tale about fostering healthy relationships with your children so that they don't end up parenting you, like in this advert. merry christmas!
author: @fontaine9-4
text_final: so, emotionally stunted man has insidious pernicious resentment (25 old?) autistic son because grew up. son (a people pleaser due father's neglect) mirrors father's awkwardness too scared hand thoughtful gift naively hopes make father validate autonomous person love unconditionally. father too selfish do continues infantalise son point picturing newborn, albeit now at least showing some affection which has clearly been lacking throughout life. should cautionary tale fostering healthy relationships children so don't end up parenting you, like advert. merry christmas!

text: 46 year old dad here, i have a 14 year old daughter grace (going on 18 it feels) and this really hit me. we have a great relationship but can't remember the last time i had a hug from her. it's been the occasional fist bump here and there with a good bit of banter from time to time. for the son in the video to be anticipating his dads response was perfect and then for the dad to do some dad dancing with the son smiling at the end was great. also the daughter and mum in the background made it so wholesome. such a warm, nostalgic and reflective take on parenting teenagers in todays world. bravo jl.
author: @stephen2nd007
text_final: 46 old dad here, 14 old daughter grace (going on 18 feels) really hit me. great relationship but can't remember last time had hug from her. been occasional fist bump here there good bit banter from time time. son video anticipating dads response perfect then dad do some dad dancing son smiling at end great. also daughter mum background made so wholesome. such warm, nostalgic reflective take on parenting teenagers todays world. bravo jl.

text: ah yes… i was young once my boy… what a beautiful gift, seeing his dad as more than a dad… as a man with a world deep inside his soul, a world that doesn’t exist anymore, other than in the nostalgic rhythm resuscitating a youthful life overspilling with fun, freedom, fallouts & fall-ins. where responsibility was for anyone but us, and life was up for grabs, especially on the weekends…. and seeing you my boy, here with me now, is everything folded hands much respect to all the mammy’s & daddy’s & the silent discos in their souls…. and for the kids who hear the tune & feel the rhythm….
author: @DaMondolorian
text_final: ah yes… young once boy… what beautiful gift, seeing dad more than dad… man world deep inside soul, world doesn’t exist anymore, other than nostalgic rhythm resuscitating youthful life overspilling fun, freedom, fallouts fall-ins. where responsibility anyone but us, life up grabs, especially on weekends…. seeing boy, here now, everything folded hands much respect all mammy’s daddy’s silent discos souls…. kids hear tune feel rhythm….
